data.title: AI Teaching OS - Full Platform Build
data.description:
Build the complete AI Teaching OS platform - a K-12 education platform with 5 interconnected modules plus a Student AI Tutor. Built as a single Next.js web application (no Chrome extension) with creative use of Anthropic's Claude Opus API.

## Modules
1. Instructional Design Engine (planning, content generation, differentiation)
2. Assessment Intelligence (grading, feedback, mastery tracking)
3. Special Education & Compliance (IEP workflows, compliance, progress monitoring)
4. Family Engagement (parent communication, progress narratives)
5. District Intelligence (admin dashboards, analytics)
6. Student AI Tutor (Socratic tutoring)

## Tech Stack
- Next.js 15 with App Router, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, shadcn/ui
- Prisma with SQLite
- Anthropic Claude API (Opus) for all AI features
- NextAuth.js for authentication

## Key Constraints
- No Chrome extension - everything in one platform
- Creative use of Opus (Anthropic hackathon project)
- Full test coverage with endpoint verification

data.title: Extract shared tool-use response extraction into helper utility
data.description:
## Problem
The 4-line tool-use block extraction pattern is copy-pasted 18 times across all AI service files and 2 API routes:

```typescript
const toolUseBlock = response.content.find(
  (block): block is Extract<typeof block, { type: 'tool_use' }> => block.type === 'tool_use'
)
if (!toolUseBlock) {
  throw new Error('AI did not return structured data. Please try again.')
}
return toolUseBlock.input as SomeType
```

This appears in:
- src/lib/ai/generate-rubric.ts
- src/lib/ai/generate-lesson-plan.ts
- src/lib/ai/generate-assignment.ts
- src/lib/ai/generate-quiz.ts
- src/lib/ai/differentiate.ts
- src/lib/ai/grade-submission.ts (x2)
- src/lib/ai/iep-service.ts (x4)
- src/lib/ai/parent-communication.ts (x3)
- src/lib/ai/district-insights.ts
- src/lib/ai/report-card.ts
- src/app/api/mastery/gaps/route.ts
- src/app/api/assignments/generate/route.ts

## Why It Matters
If the Anthropic SDK changes how tool_use blocks are structured, or if you want to add logging, error context, or validation to this extraction, you need to update 18 locations. A single helper function in src/lib/ai.ts would centralize this.

## Suggested Fix
Add to src/lib/ai.ts:

```typescript
export function extractToolResult<T>(
  response: Anthropic.Message,
  errorMessage = 'AI did not return structured data'
): T {
  const toolUseBlock = response.content.find(
    (block): block is Extract<typeof block, { type: 'tool_use' }> => block.type === 'tool_use'
  )
  if (!toolUseBlock) {
    throw new Error(`${errorMessage}. Please try again.`)
  }
  return toolUseBlock.input as T
}
```

Then replace all 18 instances with `return extractToolResult<GeneratedRubric>(response)` (or the appropriate type).

data.title: assignments/generate/route.ts duplicates AI service and bypasses singleton
data.description:
## Problem
src/app/api/assignments/generate/route.ts has three related issues:

1. **Duplicate Anthropic client**: Creates its own Anthropic instance (line 14: `const anthropic = new Anthropic(...)`) instead of importing the global singleton from `@/lib/ai.ts`. This bypasses the hot-reload protection and could create multiple clients in development.

2. **Hardcoded model string**: Uses the literal string `'claude-opus-4-6'` (line 76) instead of the `AI_MODEL` constant from `@/lib/ai.ts`. If the model changes, this route will be missed.

3. **Duplicated tool schema**: Defines the entire Smart Assignment tool schema inline (~100 lines, lines 79-183) despite `src/lib/ai/generate-assignment.ts` already implementing `generateSmartAssignment()` with the same tool schema in a richer, more detailed form with better prompt engineering. The route should call the existing AI service function instead.

## Why It Matters
This is the most significant pattern violation in the codebase. The AI service layer exists specifically to encapsulate Claude API calls, but this route circumvents it entirely. Any change to the model, API configuration, or assignment generation prompt requires updating two locations. The inline tool schema also has less detailed property descriptions than the service version, so the two will produce different quality results.

## Suggested Fix
Refactor to use the existing `generateSmartAssignment()` from `@/lib/ai/generate-assignment.ts`:

```typescript
import { generateSmartAssignment } from '@/lib/ai/generate-assignment'
// ...
const generated = await generateSmartAssignment({ objective, subject, gradeLevel, type, standards })
```

Then use the result to save to the database, which the route already does correctly.

data.title: Dead code: generateQuiz and differentiateContent AI services are unused
data.description:
## Problem
Two AI service files have no consumers anywhere in the application:

1. **src/lib/ai/generate-quiz.ts** - `generateQuiz()` is exported from the barrel index.ts but never imported by any API route, page, or component. The quiz schema tables (`quizzes`, `quizQuestions`, `questionStandards` in src/lib/db/schema/quizzes.ts) are also unused outside seed data and schema definitions.

2. **src/lib/ai/differentiate.ts** - `differentiateContent()` is exported from the barrel index.ts but never imported by any API route, page, or component.

Both are fully implemented AI service functions with tool schemas, but there are no API routes wired up to call them.

## Why It Matters
These files add ~240 lines of code that increases maintenance surface without providing any value to the running application. They also create the misleading impression that quiz generation and standalone differentiation are functional features. Any developer exploring the codebase would need to trace through imports to discover these are dead ends.

## Suggested Fix
Two options:

**Option A (if these features are planned):** Keep the AI service files but add a comment at the top of each: `// NOTE: Not yet wired to an API route.` Remove them from the barrel index.ts exports until they have consumers.

**Option B (if not planned):** Remove generate-quiz.ts, differentiate.ts, and their exports from src/lib/ai/index.ts. Remove the quiz schema tables from src/lib/db/schema/quizzes.ts if they also have no migration dependencies.

data.title: AI barrel export (src/lib/ai/index.ts) is unused -- all consumers import directly
data.description:
## Problem
src/lib/ai/index.ts carefully re-exports every function and type from all 11 AI service files (69 lines of explicit exports including type aliases to resolve naming conflicts). However, every consumer in the application imports directly from the individual files:

- `from '@/lib/ai/grade-submission'`
- `from '@/lib/ai/iep-service'`
- `from '@/lib/ai/tutor'`
- `from '@/lib/ai/parent-communication'`
- etc.

Zero API routes or pages import from `@/lib/ai/index.ts`.

Additionally, the barrel contains a `ProgressNarrativeInput as ParentProgressNarrativeInput` rename to resolve a name collision between iep-service.ts and parent-communication.ts (both export `ProgressNarrativeInput`). This rename only exists in the barrel that nobody uses.

## Why It Matters
The barrel index is 69 lines of code that serves no purpose and creates a maintenance obligation: every time an AI service function is added, the barrel must be updated too. Since no consumer uses it, it can silently fall out of sync.

## Suggested Fix
Either:

**Option A:** Delete the barrel exports from src/lib/ai/index.ts (keep only the Anthropic client and AI_MODEL constant re-export, which are legitimately used). The direct imports are a fine pattern for a codebase this size.

**Option B:** Establish a convention to import from the barrel and update all consumer imports. This would require resolving the ProgressNarrativeInput naming collision (rename one of the source types instead).

Option A is simpler and honest about the actual import pattern.

data.title: Inline AI call in mastery/gaps/route.ts bypasses the AI service layer
data.description:
## Problem
src/app/api/mastery/gaps/route.ts directly imports `anthropic` and `AI_MODEL` from `@/lib/ai` and makes an inline Anthropic API call (lines 161-222) to generate reteach activity recommendations. This includes a complete tool schema definition and response extraction inline in the route handler.

Every other AI feature in the codebase goes through a dedicated service function in src/lib/ai/. This route is the sole exception (along with assignments/generate, tracked separately).

The AI service layer pattern exists so that prompt engineering, tool schemas, and API call configuration are centralized and reusable. Having inline AI calls in route handlers makes it harder to find all the places where Claude is called, harder to update prompts globally, and harder to add cross-cutting concerns like logging or rate limiting.

Extract the reteach recommendations into a new function in a service file (e.g., `src/lib/ai/grade-submission.ts` since it's assessment-related, or a new `src/lib/ai/reteach.ts`):

```typescript

  gapSummary: string
): Promise<{ standardCode: string; activities: string[]; groupingStrategy: string }[]>
```

Then call it from the route.

data.title: Rubrics GET route fetches ALL criteria then filters in JavaScript
data.description:
## Problem
In src/app/api/rubrics/route.ts (lines 23-31), the GET handler fetches all rubric criteria from the entire database and then filters by rubric ID in JavaScript:

```typescript
const allCriteria = await db
  .select({ rubricId: rubricCriteria.rubricId })
  .from(rubricCriteria)

for (const c of allCriteria) {
  if (rubricIds.includes(c.rubricId)) {
    criteriaByRubric[c.rubricId] = (criteriaByRubric[c.rubricId] ?? 0) + 1
  }
}
```

This fetches every row from `rubric_criteria` regardless of how many rubrics belong to the current teacher. As the criteria table grows, this becomes increasingly wasteful.

## Why It Matters
For a small dataset this is harmless, but the pattern transfers poorly as data grows. Every rubric with 4 criteria means 4 rows fetched unnecessarily. With 100 teachers and 50 rubrics each, the query returns 20,000 rows to count criteria for one teacher's rubrics.

## Suggested Fix
Use a SQL `WHERE ... IN` clause to filter at the database level:

```typescript
const allCriteria = await db
  .select({ rubricId: rubricCriteria.rubricId })
  .from(rubricCriteria)
  .where(inArray(rubricCriteria.rubricId, rubricIds))
```

Or better, use a single query with GROUP BY:

```typescript
const criteriaCounts = await db
  .select({
    rubricId: rubricCriteria.rubricId,
    count: sql<number>`count(*)`,
  })
  .from(rubricCriteria)
  .where(inArray(rubricCriteria.rubricId, rubricIds))
  .groupBy(rubricCriteria.rubricId)
```

data.title: Bug: Students API .where() replaces role filter in dynamic query
data.description:
## Context
The GET handler in `/api/admin/students/route.ts` builds a dynamic Drizzle query with an optional search filter.

## Problem
In Drizzle ORM, calling `.where()` on a `$dynamic()` query **replaces** the previous WHERE clause rather than appending with AND. The code at lines 31-45 does:

```typescript
let studentQuery = db
  .select(...)
  .from(users)
  .where(eq(users.role, 'student'))  // First where
  .$dynamic()

if (search) {
  studentQuery = studentQuery.where(  // REPLACES first where
    sql`${users.role} = 'student' and (...ilike...)`
  )
}
```

The second `.where()` replaces the first. The code works today only because the SQL template at line 43 manually re-includes `${users.role} = 'student'`. However:

1. This pattern is fragile -- a developer modifying the search filter who doesn't understand that `.where()` replaces (rather than ANDs) could easily remove the role check, exposing non-student user data to admins.
2. It duplicates the role filter logic in two places.

## Evidence
File: `src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts`, lines 31-45

## Fix
Use Drizzle's `and()` helper to compose conditions:

```typescript
const conditions = [eq(users.role, 'student')]
if (search) {
  conditions.push(
    or(
      ilike(users.name, '%' + search + '%'),
      ilike(users.email, '%' + search + '%')
    )!
  )
}

const allStudents = await db
  .select({ id: users.id, name: users.name, email: users.email })
  .from(users)

data.title: Admin routes use sequential queries in Promise.all loops (N+1 pattern)
data.description:
## Problem
Two admin API routes use Promise.all with per-entity sequential database queries, creating an N+1 query pattern:

1. **src/app/api/admin/schools/route.ts** (lines 35-106): For each school, runs 4-5 separate queries (class IDs, teacher count, student count, assignment count, avg score). With 10 schools, this fires ~50 database queries.

2. **src/app/api/admin/teachers/route.ts** (lines 39-97): For each teacher, runs 4 separate queries (school, class count, assignment count, graded count, feedback count). With 20 teachers, this fires ~100 database queries.

Both use `Promise.all(allEntities.map(async (entity) => { ...multiple await db... }))`.

## Why It Matters
This pattern works for the current small seed data (2 schools, 5 teachers) but scales linearly with data growth. A district with 50 schools and 200 teachers would issue hundreds of database queries per admin dashboard load. The Promise.all provides concurrency but not efficiency -- each entity still requires its own round-trips.

## Suggested Fix
Batch the queries using SQL JOINs, subqueries, or Drizzle's aggregate functions to fetch all the data in 1-3 queries total, then assemble results in JavaScript. For example, for the schools route:

```typescript
const schoolStats = await db
  .select({
    schoolId: classes.schoolId,
    classCount: sql<number>`count(distinct ${classes.id})`,
    teacherCount: sql<number>`count(distinct case when ${classMembers.role} = 'teacher' then ${classMembers.userId} end)`,
    studentCount: sql<number>`count(distinct case when ${classMembers.role} = 'student' then ${classMembers.userId} end)`,
  })
  .from(classes)
  .leftJoin(classMembers, eq(classes.id, classMembers.classId))
  .groupBy(classes.schoolId)
```

data.title: Bug: Unguarded JSON.parse in report cards GET crashes on malformed data
data.description:
## Context
The report cards API routes parse JSON string fields (strengths, areasForGrowth, recommendations) from the database before returning them to clients.

## Problem
Multiple `JSON.parse()` calls in both `/api/report-cards/route.ts` and `/api/report-cards/[id]/route.ts` have no try/catch protection. If any stored JSON field is malformed (corrupt write, manual DB edit, migration issue), the parse throws and crashes the entire request.

The GET listing endpoint at lines 84-91 is especially vulnerable:

```typescript
return NextResponse.json(
  results.map((r) => ({
    ...r,
    strengths: r.strengths ? JSON.parse(r.strengths) : [],      // line 87
    areasForGrowth: r.areasForGrowth ? JSON.parse(r.areasForGrowth) : [],  // line 88
    recommendations: r.recommendations ? JSON.parse(r.recommendations) : [],  // line 89
  }))
)
```

One corrupt record in the database will crash the `.map()` and prevent ALL report cards from being listed. This is a single-bad-record-poisons-everything scenario.

The same pattern exists in the GET by ID route (line 74-76) and the PUT route (lines 150-152 and 180-182).

Notably, the code at line 265-268 (feedback highlights parsing) DOES have a try/catch -- showing the author was aware of the risk in some cases but missed it in others.

## Evidence
- `src/app/api/report-cards/route.ts` lines 87-89 (no try/catch)
- `src/app/api/report-cards/[id]/route.ts` lines 74-76, 150-152, 180-182 (no try/catch)
- `src/app/api/report-cards/route.ts` lines 265-268 (HAS try/catch -- inconsistency)
- CODE_GUIDE: "Fail explicitly -- no silent fallbacks"

## Fix
Wrap each JSON.parse in a try/catch or use a safe parse utility:

```typescript
function safeJsonParse(value: string | null, fallback: unknown[] = []): unknown {
  if (!value) return fallback
  try { return JSON.parse(value) } catch { return fallback }
}
```

data.title: Bug: AI service return types use unsafe 'as' assertions on external data
data.description:
## Context
The AI service files `district-insights.ts` and `report-card.ts` call the Anthropic API with tool_use and then return the tool input as typed data.

## Problem
Both files use `as` type assertions to cast the AI-generated tool_use input to their TypeScript interfaces without any runtime validation:

```typescript
// district-insights.ts line 120
return toolUseBlock.input as DistrictInsights

// report-card.ts line 161
return toolUseBlock.input as GeneratedReportCard
```

The `toolUseBlock.input` is `unknown` -- it comes from an external AI API response. The `as` assertion tells TypeScript to trust the shape without checking it. If the AI returns data with:
- Missing required fields (e.g., no `executiveSummary`)
- Wrong types (e.g., `keyFindings` as a string instead of string[])
- Extra or renamed fields

...the assertion will silently pass, and downstream code will fail with cryptic runtime errors (e.g., `Cannot read properties of undefined`, `map is not a function`).

This violates the CODE_GUIDE: "Never use `any` -- use `unknown` with type guards instead" and "Validate external data (HTTP, files, user input) with schema validation (Zod, etc.) at boundaries."

## Evidence
- `src/lib/ai/district-insights.ts` line 120
- `src/lib/ai/report-card.ts` line 161
- Same pattern exists in other AI service files (generate-rubric.ts, generate-lesson-plan.ts, etc.) but those are not in scope for this review

## Fix
Add Zod schemas to validate the AI response at runtime:

```typescript
import { z } from 'zod'

const districtInsightsSchema = z.object({
  executiveSummary: z.string(),
  keyFindings: z.array(z.string()),
  concerns: z.array(z.string()),
  recommendations: z.array(z.string()),
})

// Then:
return districtInsightsSchema.parse(toolUseBlock.input)
```

data.title: Performance: N+1 query pattern in admin teachers, students, and schools routes
data.description:
## Context
Three admin API routes fetch a list of entities and then run multiple queries per entity inside a Promise.all(entities.map(...)) loop.

## Problem
The pattern creates O(N * M) database round trips where N is the number of entities and M is the number of sub-queries per entity.

### /api/admin/teachers/route.ts (lines 39-97)
For each teacher: 4 queries (school lookup, class count, assignment count, graded count, feedback count).
With 50 teachers = 200 DB queries per request.

### /api/admin/students/route.ts (lines 49-101)
For each student: 3 queries (classes, avg score, mastery distribution).
With 100 students = 300 DB queries per request.

### /api/admin/schools/route.ts (lines 35-106)
For each school: up to 5 queries (classes, teacher count, student count, assignment count, avg score).
With 20 schools = 100 DB queries per request.

All of these can be replaced with JOINs and subqueries that execute in 1-3 database round trips total. The Promise.all provides concurrency within a single entity but does not reduce total query count.

## Evidence
- `src/app/api/admin/teachers/route.ts` lines 39-97
- `src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts` lines 49-101
- `src/app/api/admin/schools/route.ts` lines 35-106

## Fix
Replace the map-per-entity pattern with aggregating JOINs. Example for teachers:

```sql
SELECT u.id, u.name, u.email, u.role,
  (SELECT s.name FROM class_members cm 
   JOIN classes c ON cm.class_id = c.id 
   LEFT JOIN schools s ON c.school_id = s.id 
   WHERE cm.user_id = u.id AND cm.role = 'teacher' LIMIT 1) as school,
  count(distinct a.id) as assignments_created,
  ...
FROM users u
LEFT JOIN assignments a ON a.teacher_id = u.id
...
WHERE u.role IN ('teacher', 'sped_teacher')
GROUP BY u.id
```

data.title: Bug: Student PII (real name) sent to Anthropic API in report card generation
data.description:
## Context
The report card generation feature sends student data to the Anthropic API to generate narrative comments.

## Problem
The student's real name is included directly in the AI prompt. In `src/app/api/report-cards/route.ts` line 280:

```typescript
const generated = await generateReportCardNarrative({
  studentName: student.name ?? 'Student',
  ...
})
```

And in `src/lib/ai/report-card.ts` line 131, this name is interpolated directly into the prompt:

```
Student: ${input.studentName}
```

This means "Aisha Torres" or "DeShawn Williams" -- real student names -- are sent to the Anthropic API as part of the request body.

The PRD Section 10 (Data Privacy & Compliance) states under "AI Model Data Handling":
- "Prompts stripped of direct identifiers; PII re-associated only in the response layer"

The current implementation contradicts this architectural requirement. While Anthropic's API may not retain the data, sending PII at all violates the stated architecture and could be a compliance concern during a SOC 2 audit or district DPA review.

## Evidence
- `src/app/api/report-cards/route.ts` line 280: `studentName: student.name ?? 'Student'`
- `src/lib/ai/report-card.ts` line 131: `Student: ${input.studentName}`
- PRD Section 10: "Prompts stripped of direct identifiers"

## Fix
Use a placeholder like "the student" or "Student" in the AI prompt, then replace it with the real name in the response layer before storing/returning the report card.

```typescript
const generated = await generateReportCardNarrative({
  studentName: 'the student',  // anonymized for AI
  ...
})

// Re-associate name in stored narrative
const narrative = generated.overallNarrative.replace(/the student/gi, student.name ?? 'Student')
```

data.title: Admin API routes lack district-level data scoping (multi-tenancy gap)
data.description:
## Context
The admin API routes serve District Intelligence dashboards. In a multi-district deployment, each admin should only see data for their own district.

## Problem
All six admin API routes (/api/admin/overview, analytics, schools, teachers, students, insights) query across ALL data in the database without filtering by the admin user's district.

The auth check only verifies the user has role 'admin' or 'district_admin':
```typescript
if (session.user.role !== 'admin' && session.user.role !== 'district_admin') {
  return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Forbidden' }, { status: 403 })
}
```

But there is:
1. No `districtId` field on the user record in the `users` schema
2. No `schoolId` field on the user record
3. No filtering of schools/teachers/students by district in any admin query

This means:
- A `district_admin` from District A sees all data from Districts A, B, C, etc.
- Student counts, teacher counts, mastery data, grading metrics -- all cross district boundaries
- The `/api/admin/insights` POST sends ALL district data to the AI, including data from other districts

The PRD Section 10 states: "Role-based at the database level. Teachers see only their students. Principals see only their building." The admin routes violate this principle at the district level.

## Evidence
- `src/app/api/admin/overview/route.ts`: queries `users`, `schools`, `classes`, `assignments`, `submissions` tables with no district filter
- `src/app/api/admin/analytics/route.ts`: same pattern
- `src/app/api/admin/teachers/route.ts`: same pattern
- `src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts`: same pattern
- `src/app/api/admin/schools/route.ts`: same pattern
- `src/app/api/admin/insights/route.ts`: same pattern
- `src/lib/db/schema/auth.ts`: `users` table has no `districtId` or `schoolId` column

## Fix
1. Add a `schoolId` or `districtId` column to the `users` table (or derive it from class/school membership)
2. In each admin route, resolve the admin's district and filter all queries by that district
3. For the interim, add a comment documenting the single-tenant assumption

data.title: CRITICAL: Registration endpoint allows arbitrary role assignment (privilege escalation)
data.description:
## Bug

The `/api/auth/register` endpoint (src/app/api/auth/register/route.ts:9,35) accepts a `role` parameter directly from the request body and passes it to the database without validation:

```typescript
const { name, email, password, role } = await req.json()
// ...
const [user] = await db.insert(users).values({
  name, email, passwordHash,
  role: role || 'teacher',
})
```

Any unauthenticated user can register as `admin`, `district_admin`, `sped_teacher`, or any role by sending `{ "role": "admin" }` in the POST body. This grants full access to the admin dashboard, all student PII, IEP data (FERPA/IDEA-protected), district-wide analytics, and the ability to generate AI insights on sensitive aggregate data.

## Impact

- **Privilege escalation**: Anyone can self-assign admin role
- **Data exposure**: Admin role exposes all student PII, SPED data, IEP records
- **Compliance violation**: FERPA and IDEA data accessible without authorization
- **This is the most critical security issue in the application**

## Evidence

File: `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/auth/register/route.ts`, lines 9 and 31-36

## Fix

Either:
1. Remove the `role` parameter from registration entirely (hardcode to `'teacher'` for self-registration)
2. Or validate `role` against an allowlist of self-assignable roles (e.g., only `teacher`), and require an admin to assign elevated roles

Option 1 is strongly recommended:
```typescript
const [user] = await db.insert(users).values({
  name, email, passwordHash,
  role: 'teacher', // Only teachers can self-register
}).returning()
```

data.title: CRITICAL: Admin API routes have no district/school scoping — any admin sees all data
data.description:
## Bug

All six admin API routes check for `admin` or `district_admin` role but never scope the data to the admin's district or school. Every admin/district_admin sees the entire database regardless of organizational affiliation.

### Affected routes:
- `/api/admin/overview` (src/app/api/admin/overview/route.ts) - counts all schools, teachers, students globally
- `/api/admin/analytics` (src/app/api/admin/analytics/route.ts) - aggregates all mastery, submissions, teacher engagement globally
- `/api/admin/schools` (src/app/api/admin/schools/route.ts) - returns all schools
- `/api/admin/teachers` (src/app/api/admin/teachers/route.ts) - returns all teachers
- `/api/admin/students` (src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts) - returns all students with scores and mastery
- `/api/admin/insights` (src/app/api/admin/insights/route.ts) - sends all aggregate data to AI

### Problem

The `users` table has no `districtId` or `schoolId` field, so there is no mechanism to scope admin queries to their jurisdiction. A district_admin at District A can see all students, grades, IEP data, and teacher engagement from District B.

Combined with the registration privilege escalation bug (anyone can register as admin), this means any anonymous user can access the entire database by registering as `admin`.

## Impact

- **Multi-tenant data leak**: Districts see each other's data
- **FERPA violation**: Student educational records visible across district boundaries
- **Compliance blocker**: District-level data isolation is a stated architectural requirement (VISION-PRD section 10)

## Evidence

All six files in `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/admin/` query tables without any WHERE clause filtering by the admin's organizational affiliation.

## Fix

1. Add `schoolId` or `districtId` to the `users` table (or use the classMembers/schools relationship)
2. Filter all admin queries by the admin's district/school
3. District admins see only their district; school admins see only their school

data.title: IMPORTANT: Messages API fetches entire users table to resolve names
data.description:
## Bug

In `/api/messages/route.ts` GET handler (lines 39-55), when resolving sender/receiver names, the code fetches ALL users from the database regardless of how many are needed:

```typescript
const userNames: Record<string, string> = {}
if (userIds.length > 0) {
  const usersResult = await db
    .select({ id: users.id, name: users.name })
    .from(users) // <-- No WHERE clause! Fetches entire users table

  for (const u of usersResult) {
    if (userIds.includes(u.id)) {
      userNames[u.id] = u.name ?? 'Unknown'
    }
  }
}
```

The query has no WHERE clause. It fetches every user row, then filters in JavaScript. With the target of 50M students in the PRD, this would load 50M+ rows for every messages API call.

## Impact

- **Performance**: O(n) memory and time where n = total users in the system
- **At scale**: Will cause out-of-memory errors or extreme latency
- **Happens on every messages page load**

## Evidence

File: `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/messages/route.ts`, lines 46-54

## Fix

Use `inArray` to filter to only the needed user IDs:

```typescript
const usersResult = await db
  .select({ id: users.id, name: users.name })
  .from(users)
  .where(inArray(users.id, userIds))
```

data.title: IMPORTANT: Grading route has no role check — any authenticated user can grade submissions
data.description:
## Bug

The POST handler at `/api/grading/route.ts` and `/api/grading/batch/route.ts` check authentication but do not check the user's role before allowing grading operations. They verify teacher assignment ownership, but a student or parent who happens to know an assignment ID could attempt to grade submissions.

While the teacher ownership check on the assignment provides some protection, the route's GET handler (lines 17-71) also lacks a role check — it simply fetches all submissions for assignments where `teacherId = session.user.id`. For non-teacher users, this returns an empty array rather than a 403, which is an information disclosure issue (confirms the user has no assignments rather than rejecting unauthorized access).

The same issue exists in:
- `/api/grading/[submissionId]/route.ts` GET and PUT — no role check
- `/api/mastery/update/route.ts` POST — no role check; any authenticated user can create mastery records

### Broader pattern:
Several non-admin routes lack role checks entirely:
- `/api/grading/*` — no role checks (relies on ownership checks only)
- `/api/mastery/update` — no role check at all
- `/api/messages/translate` — no role check (any user can trigger AI translation, burning API credits)
- `/api/assignments/route.ts`, `/api/rubrics/route.ts`, `/api/lesson-plans/route.ts` — need to verify

## Impact

- **Authorization bypass**: Users in wrong roles can access teacher-only endpoints
- **API cost**: Any authenticated user can trigger AI calls (translate, grading)
- **Defense in depth**: Role checks are the first line of defense; relying solely on ownership checks is fragile

## Evidence

- `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/grading/route.ts` lines 17-22 (GET) and 74-78 (POST) — auth check only, no role check
- `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/grading/batch/route.ts` lines 16-20 — auth check only
- `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/mastery/update/route.ts` lines 22-26 — auth check only
- `/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/messages/translate/route.ts` lines 5-9 — auth check only

## Fix

Add role checks to all teacher-facing endpoints:
```typescript
if (session.user.role !== 'teacher' && session.user.role !== 'sped_teacher') {
  return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Forbidden: teacher role required' }, { status: 403 })
}
```

IMPORTANT: Admin students search builds duplicate WHERE conditions (overrides role filter)
data.description:
## Bug

In `/api/admin/students/route.ts` (lines 31-45), the dynamic query builds a WHERE clause for `role = 'student'`, then when a search parameter is provided, it calls `.where()` AGAIN with a new condition:

```typescript
let studentQuery = db
  .select({ ... })
  .from(users)
  .where(eq(users.role, 'student'))  // First where: role = student
  .\$dynamic()

if (search) {
  studentQuery = studentQuery.where(
    sql\`\${users.role} = 'student' and (\${users.name} ilike ...\`
  )
}
```

Using Drizzle's \`\$dynamic()\` followed by a second \`.where()\` call replaces the first WHERE clause entirely rather than ANDing with it. The code recognizes this risk and duplicates the role check inside the raw SQL template, but this pattern is fragile and error-prone.

Additionally, the search uses raw SQL string interpolation for the ILIKE pattern:
```typescript
sql\`... \${users.name} ilike \${'%' + search + '%'} ...\`
```

While Drizzle's \`sql\` template tag parameterizes these values safely, the pattern of building search conditions via raw SQL templates is less maintainable than using Drizzle's typed operators (\`ilike\` from drizzle-orm).

## Impact

- **Correctness risk**: The duplicate WHERE pattern is fragile — future edits that remove the duplicated role check from the raw SQL would expose non-student data to the search
- **Maintainability**: Raw SQL search conditions are harder to verify for correctness

## Evidence

File: \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts\`, lines 31-45

## Fix

Use Drizzle's typed query builder with \`and()\` to compose conditions:

```typescript
const conditions = [eq(users.role, 'student')]
if (search) {
  conditions.push(
    or(
      ilike(users.name, \`%\${search}%\`),
      ilike(users.email, \`%\${search}%\`)
    )
  )
}
const allStudents = await db
  .select({ ... })
  .from(users)
  .where(and(...conditions))
```

data.title: Pervasive JSON.parse/JSON.stringify for structured columns has no helper or type safety
data.description:
## Problem

The codebase stores structured data as JSON strings in text columns (levels, criteria descriptors, standards, objectives, materials, differentiation, strengths, improvements, etc.). Every read and write requires manual JSON.parse and JSON.stringify, with no centralized helper or type safety.

Across the API routes, there are **60+ raw JSON.parse calls** and **30+ raw JSON.stringify calls**. Many of them repeat the same pattern for the same field. For example, the lesson plan JSON parse block appears in 3 separate locations:

**src/app/api/lesson-plans/route.ts** (lines 21-25, GET):
```typescript
standards: plan.standards ? JSON.parse(plan.standards) : [],
objectives: JSON.parse(plan.objectives),
materials: plan.materials ? JSON.parse(plan.materials) : [],
differentiation: plan.differentiation ? JSON.parse(plan.differentiation) : null,
aiMetadata: plan.aiMetadata ? JSON.parse(plan.aiMetadata) : null,
```

**src/app/api/lesson-plans/route.ts** (lines 88-92, POST response):
```typescript
// Exact same 5-line pattern repeated
```

**src/app/api/lesson-plans/generate/route.ts** (lines 75-81, POST response):
```typescript
// Exact same 5-line pattern repeated a third time
```

The rubric descriptors parsing pattern (`JSON.parse(c.descriptors) as Record<string, string>`) appears in 8 separate files. The report card fields (strengths, areasForGrowth, recommendations) are parsed identically in 4 locations.

None of these JSON.parse calls have try/catch protection. Malformed JSON in the database would crash the route handler with an unhandled error.

## Why It Matters

1. **Maintenance cost**: Changing how any JSON field is structured requires finding every JSON.parse/stringify call for that field across multiple files
2. **Type erosion**: The `as Record<string, string>` and `as string[]` casts trust that the stored JSON matches the expected shape with no runtime validation
3. **Error handling gap**: Any corrupted JSON value in the database causes a 500 error with no helpful context
4. **Verbosity**: 60+ parse calls add noise that obscures the business logic

## Suggested Fix

Create parse/serialize helpers for each structured column type, grouped by domain. For example:

```typescript
// src/lib/db/json-fields.ts
export function parseLessonPlanFields(plan: typeof lessonPlans.$inferSelect) {
  return {
    ...plan,
    standards: safeParseArray(plan.standards),
    objectives: safeParseArray(plan.objectives),
    materials: safeParseArray(plan.materials),
    differentiation: safeParseJson(plan.differentiation),
    aiMetadata: safeParseJson(plan.aiMetadata),
  }
}

function safeParseArray(json: string | null): string[] {
  if (!json) return []
  try { return JSON.parse(json) } catch { return [] }
}

function safeParseJson<T>(json: string | null): T | null {
  if (!json) return null
  try { return JSON.parse(json) } catch { return null }
}
```

data.title: IMPORTANT: IEP detail route has N+1 query for progress data — queries one goal at a time
data.description:
## Bug

In \`/api/iep/[iepId]/route.ts\` GET handler (lines 62-77), progress data is fetched per goal in a serial loop:

```typescript
let progressData = []
if (goalIds.length > 0) {
  progressData = await db
    .select().from(progressDataPoints)
    .where(eq(progressDataPoints.goalId, goalIds[0]))

  for (let i = 1; i < goalIds.length; i++) {
    const moreData = await db
      .select().from(progressDataPoints)
      .where(eq(progressDataPoints.goalId, goalIds[i]))
    progressData.push(...moreData)
  }
}
```

This executes N sequential database queries where N = number of goals. With an IEP that has 10 goals, this is 10 database queries when 1 would suffice.

## Impact

- **Performance**: Serial (not even parallel) N+1 queries
- **Latency**: Each IEP detail page load scales linearly with goal count

## Evidence

File: \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/iep/[iepId]/route.ts\`, lines 62-77

## Fix

Use \`inArray\` to fetch all progress data in a single query:

```typescript
if (goalIds.length > 0) {
  progressData = await db
    .select()
    .from(progressDataPoints)
    .where(inArray(progressDataPoints.goalId, goalIds))
}
```

data.title: Unused imports: ilike and or from drizzle-orm in admin/students route
data.description:
## Problem

In src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts (line 10), `ilike` and `or` are imported from drizzle-orm:

```typescript
import { eq, sql, ilike, or } from 'drizzle-orm'
```

However, the search filter on line 43 uses raw SQL template strings instead of the imported Drizzle operators:

```typescript
studentQuery = studentQuery.where(
  sql\`\${users.role} = 'student' and (\${users.name} ilike \${'%' + search + '%'} or \${users.email} ilike \${'%' + search + '%'})\`
)
```

The `ilike` and `or` imports are dead code. The raw SQL also duplicates the `role = 'student'` condition that was already applied on line 38.

## Why It Matters

Dead imports are minor noise individually, but signal incomplete refactoring. The raw SQL approach also bypasses the type safety of the Drizzle query builder, and the duplicated `role = 'student'` condition is confusing -- the `.where()` call on line 43 replaces the one on line 38 (Drizzle `$dynamic()` chaining), so the first `where` is lost when a search is present. This is both a dead import and a subtle logic concern.

## Suggested Fix

Remove the unused imports and use Drizzle operators:

```typescript
import { eq, sql, ilike, or, and } from 'drizzle-orm'

// ...
if (search) {
  studentQuery = studentQuery.where(
    and(
      eq(users.role, 'student'),
      or(ilike(users.name, \`%\${search}%\`), ilike(users.email, \`%\${search}%\`))
    )
  )
}
```

```typescript
export interface ProgressNarrativeInput {
  goalText: string
  dataPoints: { date: string; value: number; notes?: string }[]

  recentScores: { assignment: string; score: number; maxScore: number; date: string }[]
  masteryData: { standard: string; standardDescription: string; level: string; score: number }[]

It also makes the codebase harder to navigate -- searching for `ProgressNarrativeInput` returns results from both files with no clear way to distinguish them.

data.title: IMPORTANT: Translation endpoint has no input length limit — unbounded AI cost
data.description:
## Bug

The \`/api/messages/translate\` endpoint (lines 5-32) and \`translateCommunication()\` function accept text of any length with no validation beyond checking the field exists. The AI call uses \`max_tokens: 4096\` for the response, but the input text has no size limit.

Similarly, the tutor streaming endpoint \`/api/tutor/route.ts\` accepts messages with no length limit (line 28 only checks \`message.trim().length === 0\`). The conversation history is also unbounded — it grows indefinitely as the session continues, eventually exceeding the model's context window.

### Affected endpoints with no input length validation:
- \`/api/messages/translate\` — unbounded \`text\` field
- \`/api/tutor\` — unbounded \`message\` field and unbounded conversation history
- \`/api/grading/route.ts\` POST — unbounded \`content\` (student work)
- \`/api/report-cards/route.ts\` POST — unbounded data aggregation sent to AI
- \`/api/admin/insights\` POST — unbounded snapshot data sent to AI

Each call to the Anthropic API has a cost. Without input limits, a malicious user can:
1. Send extremely large texts for translation (burning API credits)
2. Have extremely long tutor conversations (accumulating cost with the full history sent each time)
3. Trigger report card generation with large amounts of data

## Impact

- **Cost abuse**: Unbounded API costs from large inputs
- **API failure**: Exceeding model context window causes errors (tutor conversation history)
- **DoS vector**: Expensive AI calls triggered by unauthenticated users (via registration privilege escalation)

## Evidence

- \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/messages/translate/route.ts\`, lines 12-16 (no length check)
- \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/tutor/route.ts\`, line 28 (only checks empty, not max length)
- \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/lib/ai/tutor.ts\`, line 103-108 (full conversation history sent each time)

## Fix

1. Add input length limits (e.g., text max 10,000 chars for translation, message max 2,000 chars for tutor)
2. Truncate or window the tutor conversation history (e.g., last 20 messages)
3. Add rate limiting per user per endpoint

data.title: MINOR: Report card and feedback JSON.parse calls lack try/catch — malformed data crashes routes
data.description:
## Bug

Multiple API routes parse JSON from text columns using \`JSON.parse()\` without try/catch protection. If the stored JSON is malformed (e.g., corrupted during an interrupted write, or a manual database edit), these routes will throw an unhandled exception and return a 500 error.

### Affected locations:

1. **Report cards GET** (\`/api/report-cards/route.ts\`, lines 87-89):
   ```typescript
   strengths: r.strengths ? JSON.parse(r.strengths) : [],
   areasForGrowth: r.areasForGrowth ? JSON.parse(r.areasForGrowth) : [],
   recommendations: r.recommendations ? JSON.parse(r.recommendations) : [],
   ```

2. **Report cards [id] GET/PUT** (\`/api/report-cards/[id]/route.ts\`, lines 74-76, 150-152, 178-182)

3. **Grading [submissionId] GET** (\`/api/grading/[submissionId]/route.ts\`, lines 104, 127-134) — parses attachments, strengths, improvements, nextSteps, aiMetadata

4. **IEP [iepId] GET** (\`/api/iep/[iepId]/route.ts\`, lines 90-98) — parses accommodations, modifications, relatedServices, transitionPlan, aiMetadata

5. **Rubric levels** (\`/api/grading/route.ts\`, line 181) — \`JSON.parse(rubric.levels)\`

The report card \`/api/report-cards/route.ts\` POST handler (lines 258-275) has a try/catch inside the feedbackHighlights parsing block (line 266), showing awareness of the issue, but this pattern is not applied consistently.

## Impact

- **Route crashes**: Any malformed JSON in the database breaks the entire route for all users
- **Poor user experience**: 500 errors with no actionable message
- **Data resilience**: System should degrade gracefully with corrupted data

## Evidence

Listed above. The most impactful is the report cards GET (line 87-89) which processes ALL report cards in a map — one bad record crashes the entire list.

## Fix

Wrap each \`JSON.parse()\` call in a try/catch with a sensible default:

```typescript
function safeJsonParse<T>(json: string | null, fallback: T): T {
  if (!json) return fallback
  try { return JSON.parse(json) } catch { return fallback }
}
```

data.title: BUG: Early warning first-name matching for AI recommendations is fragile and can produce wrong matches
data.description:
## Context
The early warning API matches AI-generated intervention recommendations back to students by comparing first names (case-insensitive). This is fragile and can produce incorrect results when multiple students share the same first name.

## Evidence
**src/app/api/early-warning/route.ts:248** — Student data sent to AI uses only first name:
```ts
const firstName = s.name.split(' ')[0]
return \`Student: \${firstName}\n...\`
```

**src/app/api/early-warning/route.ts:306-310** — Matching AI response back to students by first name:
```ts
const match = flaggedStudents.find(
  (s) => s.name.split(' ')[0].toLowerCase() === rec.firstName.toLowerCase()
)
if (match) {
  match.recommendations = rec.recommendations
}
```

If two flagged students are named "Maria Garcia" and "Maria Lopez", the AI generates recommendations for both "Maria" entries, but the matching code uses .find() which returns only the first match — so one student gets the other's recommendations.

## Impact
- Wrong intervention recommendations assigned to wrong students
- In a classroom with common first names (e.g., multiple Joshuas, Marias, Aishas), recommendations get silently mis-assigned
- Teacher may act on incorrect recommendations

## Fix
Use a unique identifier (e.g., an index or an anonymized ID) instead of first names:
- Send: "Student 1", "Student 2" etc. in the prompt
- Match back by index
- This also avoids sending PII (student names) to the AI API

data.title: BUG: Early warning sends student names (PII) directly to the Anthropic API

## Context
The early warning API sends student first names to the Anthropic Claude API in the prompt. According to the project's VISION-PRD.md, AI prompts should be "stripped of direct identifiers; PII re-associated only in the response layer" (Section 10, AI Model Data Handling).

const firstName = s.name.split(' ')[0]

- If this data were logged or retained by the AI provider, it creates a FERPA exposure

const missingCount = recentAssignmentIds.filter(

).length

BUG: Early warning page renders React fragments without keys, causing React rendering warnings
data.description:
## Context
The early warning dashboard page renders table rows inside a bare React fragment (<>...</>) without a key prop. When a list renders fragments as direct children of an array, React requires a key on the outermost element.

## Evidence
**src/app/dashboard/early-warning/page.tsx:266-369:**
```tsx
{students.map((student) => {
  ...
  return (
    <>
      <TableRow key={student.id} ...>
        ...
      </TableRow>
      {isExpanded && hasRecommendations && (
        <TableRow key={\`\${student.id}-detail\`} ...>
          ...
        </TableRow>
      )}
    </>
  )
})}
```

The key is on the inner <TableRow> elements, but NOT on the outer fragment (<>). React will emit a warning: "Each child in a list should have a unique key prop."

## Impact
- React console warning in development
- Potentially incorrect DOM reconciliation if rows reorder

## Fix
Replace `<>` with `<Fragment key={student.id}>` or use React.Fragment with the key prop:
```tsx
import { Fragment } from 'react'
...
return (
  <Fragment key={student.id}>
    <TableRow>...</TableRow>
    {isExpanded && ...}
  </Fragment>
)
```

## Context
The early warning score calculation uses a fallback of maxScore ?? 100, but if maxScore is explicitly 0 (not null), the division proceeds with zero and produces NaN or Infinity.

.map((s) => Math.round(((s.totalScore ?? 0) / (s.maxScore ?? 100)) * 100))

- Could cause incorrect risk level assignments
- Math.round(NaN) returns NaN, which would render as "NaN%" in the UI

## Fix
Use a guard: (s.maxScore ?? 100) || 100 — or check for zero explicitly before dividing.

data.title: BUG: Batch report card generation processes students sequentially with no timeout protection — can hang indefinitely for large classes
data.description:
## Context
The batch report card endpoint processes each student sequentially in a for-loop, making one AI API call per student. For a class of 30 students, this could take 30+ sequential AI calls (each potentially 10-30 seconds), totaling 5-15 minutes. The HTTP request will likely time out before completion, and the client has no visibility into progress.

## Evidence
**src/app/api/report-cards/batch/route.ts:130-271:**
```ts
for (const studentId of studentIds) {
  // ... multiple DB queries per student ...
  const generatedCard = await generateReportCardNarrative({...})
  await db.insert(reportCards).values({...})
}
```

The batch-generate-dialog.tsx shows a progress bar stuck at 100% (line 159: style={{ width: '100%' }}) with no actual progress tracking — it is a fake progress indicator.

**Comparison:** The client dialog shows "generating" state but the progress bar immediately fills (it is static CSS, not driven by actual completion data). If the request times out, the user sees no error feedback — the dialog just stays in "generating" state indefinitely.

## Impact
- Classes with 20+ students will likely cause the HTTP request to time out (Vercel: 10s, most defaults: 30s-60s)
- Partial completion: some students get report cards, others do not, with no way to resume
- No progress visibility for the user

## Fix
Options:
1. Use a background job pattern: return a job ID immediately, poll for status
2. Process in batches with parallel AI calls (e.g., Promise.allSettled with concurrency limit)
3. At minimum, add a timeout guard and return partial results

data.title: BUG: Quizzes API GET loads ALL quiz_questions into memory to count them — N+0 query with full table scan
data.description:
## Context
Both the quizzes API route and the quizzes page load every single quiz question row from the database into application memory just to count questions per quiz. This is an O(total_questions) operation that will degrade as the database grows.

## Evidence
**src/app/api/quizzes/route.ts:22-30:**
```ts
const allQuestions = await db
  .select({ quizId: quizQuestions.quizId })
  .from(quizQuestions)

for (const q of allQuestions) {
  if (quizIds.includes(q.quizId)) {
    questionCountByQuiz[q.quizId] = (questionCountByQuiz[q.quizId] ?? 0) + 1
  }
}
```

**src/app/dashboard/quizzes/page.tsx:23-29** — Same pattern duplicated.

This loads ALL quiz questions from all quizzes (not just the ones being displayed), then filters in JavaScript. With 1000 quizzes at 10 questions each = 10,000 rows loaded into memory on every page load.

## Impact
- Performance degrades linearly with total quiz questions in the database
- Unnecessary memory consumption
- Duplicated code between the API route and the page component

## Fix
Use a SQL GROUP BY count:
```ts
const counts = await db
  .select({ quizId: quizQuestions.quizId, count: sql<number>\`count(*)\` })
  .from(quizQuestions)
  .where(inArray(quizQuestions.quizId, quizIds))
  .groupBy(quizQuestions.quizId)
```

## Context
The batch report card route allows both 'teacher' and 'sped_teacher' roles at the authorization level (line 24), but the class membership verification check only looks for role='teacher' in classMembers. A sped_teacher who is authorized to use the endpoint will always fail the class access check.

const [membership] = await db
  .select()
  .from(classMembers)
  .where(
    and(
      eq(classMembers.classId, classId),
      eq(classMembers.userId, session.user.id),

data.description:
## Problem

Both the quizzes API route and the quizzes page fetch every quiz question in the database to count questions per quiz, then filter in JavaScript:

In \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/api/quizzes/route.ts\` (lines 22-30):
\`\`\`ts
const allQuestions = await db
  .select({ quizId: quizQuestions.quizId })
  .from(quizQuestions)

for (const q of allQuestions) {
  if (quizIds.includes(q.quizId)) {
    questionCountByQuiz[q.quizId] = (questionCountByQuiz[q.quizId] ?? 0) + 1
  }
}
\`\`\`

In \`/Users/mark/teaching-os/src/app/dashboard/quizzes/page.tsx\` (lines 23-30):
\`\`\`ts
const allQuestions = await db
  .select({ quizId: quizQuestions.quizId })
  .from(quizQuestions)
\`\`\`

This pattern was copied from the rubrics route (tracked in TEAC-xhpeo5). Both perform an unfiltered table scan and count in JavaScript instead of using a SQL GROUP BY or an \`inArray\` WHERE clause.

## Why It Matters

At scale, this query returns every question across all quizzes in the entire system. With 100 quizzes averaging 10 questions each, that is 1000 rows transferred and iterated when only a subset is needed. The issue is compounded by the fact that the quiz route already lacks teacher scoping (TEAC-nze7ss), so it queries the entire table.

## Suggested Fix

Use a filtered query with \`inArray\`:

\`\`\`ts
const questionCounts = await db
  .select({
    quizId: quizQuestions.quizId,
    count: count(),
  })
  .from(quizQuestions)
  .where(inArray(quizQuestions.quizId, quizIds))
  .groupBy(quizQuestions.quizId)
\`\`\`

This is the same fix recommended in TEAC-xhpeo5 for rubrics.

data.title: sql count(*) returns string from postgres.js driver — Number() coercion applied only in IEP page, not in 40+ other usages across grading, dashboard, report-cards, admin API routes
data.description:
## Bug

The fix in commit 9b25bb3 correctly identified that PostgreSQL `count(*)` returns a bigint, which the `postgres.js` driver delivers as a JavaScript string at runtime. The `sql<number>` Drizzle type annotation is compile-time only and does NOT coerce the value.

The fix added `Number()` coercion in `src/app/dashboard/iep/page.tsx` (lines 151, 152, 171, 172), but the exact same `sql<number>` + `count(*)` pattern is used in 40+ other locations across the codebase that remain unfixed:

- `src/app/dashboard/page.tsx` — 15 count queries used for dashboard stats
- `src/app/dashboard/grading/page.tsx` — totalCount, gradedCount, ungradedCount used in display and arithmetic
- `src/app/dashboard/report-cards/page.tsx` — count, totalCount, draftCount, approvedCount
- `src/app/api/admin/overview/route.ts` — 10+ count queries returned in JSON
- `src/app/api/admin/analytics/route.ts` — count queries for mastery distribution
- `src/app/api/admin/teachers/route.ts` — 4 count queries
- `src/app/api/admin/students/route.ts` — count query
- `src/app/api/admin/schools/route.ts` — count query
- `src/app/api/admin/insights/route.ts` — 10+ count queries
- `src/app/api/iep/route.ts` — goalCount

## Impact

Where counts are used in strict equality (`!== 1` for pluralization), string "1" !== number 1, causing incorrect pluralization. Where counts are used in arithmetic or comparisons, JavaScript loose coercion may mask the bug in some cases but fail in others. API responses serialize string counts as `"5"` instead of `5`, which may break frontend consumers expecting numbers.

## Fix

Either:
1. Apply `Number()` coercion at every usage site (tedious, error-prone)
2. Use `cast(count(*) as int)` in the SQL template — this makes PostgreSQL return an integer which postgres.js delivers as a JS number: `sql<number>\`cast(count(*) as int)\``
3. Create a helper: `const countSql = sql<number>\`cast(count(*) as int)\`` and use it everywhere

Option 2 or 3 is the systematic fix. The Drizzle ORM docs at `.meridian/api-docs/drizzle-orm.md:829` even show this pattern.

## Evidence

The IEP page fix proves the bug exists. The same `sql<number>\`count(*)\`` pattern without coercion exists in all files listed above.

Student submissions are plain-text essays (the submissions schema at `src/lib/db/schema/submissions.ts:10` stores them as `text('content').notNull()`). When students write naturally, markdown-significant characters cause unintended formatting: - A student writing `I got 2 * 3 = 6 and then * 4 = 24` gets unexpected italics between the asterisks - `# of students` at the start of a line becomes a heading - Lines starting with `- ` or `1. ` become lists - `> quoted text` becomes a blockquote - Underscores in words like `my_variable` or `student_name` cause italics This is distinct from the other ReactMarkdown additions (AI-generated content in lesson plans, assignments, feedback, IEP present levels) where the content IS markdown generated by Claude and SHOULD be rendered. Student essay content is NOT markdown — it is plain text that should preserve its original formatting. ## Impact Student work displayed to teachers during the grading workflow may appear visually different from what the student wrote. Teachers making grading decisions could see altered formatting. This is particularly concerning for an education platform where accurate representation of student work is essential. ## Fix Revert just the submission content rendering back to plain text display: ```tsx
{submission.content}
``` Or alternatively, escape the markdown before rendering if you want the prose typography styles applied to the container. ## Evidence - `src/app/dashboard/grading/[assignmentId]/[submissionId]/page.tsx:218-219` - Seed data in `src/lib/db/seed.ts` confirms submissions are plain-text essays - The submission schema has no indication content is markdown-formatted

2. `text-sm text-stone-700 leading-relaxed prose prose-sm max-w-none` - parent/progress-narrative.tsx
3. `bg-white rounded-xl border ... text-sm text-stone-700 leading-relaxed prose prose-sm max-w-none` - grading/feedback-panel.tsx
4. `text-sm leading-relaxed prose prose-sm max-w-none` - assignments/[id]/page.tsx, lesson-plans/[id]/page.tsx
5. `prose prose-sm prose-stone max-w-none text-sm text-stone-700 leading-relaxed` - grading/[assignmentId]/[submissionId]/page.tsx
6. `text-sm text-stone-600 prose prose-sm max-w-none` - iep/[iepId]/iep-detail-tabs.tsx (text-stone-600 vs others using text-stone-700)
7. `prose prose-stone prose-sm max-w-none` - report-cards/[studentId]/page.tsx

The core pattern is `prose prose-sm max-w-none` with optional `prose-stone`. Some add `text-sm text-stone-700 leading-relaxed` (which the typography plugin already handles via prose-sm), others add `prose-stone`, others omit it. Some use text-stone-600, others text-stone-700.

The tutor chat (item 1) is a legitimate exception since it has tighter spacing for conversational UI. The layout/styling wrappers (item 3 with bg-white, border, etc.) are also fine since those are container styles, not prose styles. But the core prose class combination should be consistent.

**Suggested fix:** Define a standard prose pattern for AI-generated markdown content -- e.g. `prose prose-sm prose-stone max-w-none` -- and apply it uniformly. The `text-sm` and `leading-relaxed` classes can be dropped since `prose-sm` already sets appropriate text size and line height. Consider extracting a shared constant or a tiny wrapper component like `<MarkdownContent>{text}</MarkdownContent>` that encapsulates both the className and the ReactMarkdown rendering.

data.title: Grading rubric mapping and result persistence duplicated across 3 route files
data.description:
## Problem

The grading subsystem has three route files that each independently implement the same two operations:

**1. Rubric-to-GradeSubmissionInput mapping** (identical in all three files):
- `src/app/api/grading/route.ts` lines 177-197
- `src/app/api/grading/batch/route.ts` lines 108-126
- `src/app/api/grading/[submissionId]/route.ts` lines 290-312

Each builds the same shape: `{ title: rubric.title, levels: JSON.parse(rubric.levels), criteria: criteria.map(c => ({ id: c.id, name: c.name, description: c.description ?? '', weight: c.weight, descriptors: JSON.parse(c.descriptors) })) }` and the assignment mapping `{ title, description, instructions, subject, gradeLevel }`.

**2. Grading result persistence** (duplicated between grading/route.ts and grading/[submissionId]/route.ts regenerate):
- Insert feedbackDrafts with the same JSON.stringify calls for strengths, improvements, nextSteps, aiMetadata
- Insert criterionScores mapped identically
- Update submissions with totalScore, maxScore, letterGrade, status

## Why It Matters

When any field is added to the rubric mapping (e.g., a new criterion property) or the persistence logic changes (e.g., a new feedback field), three files must be updated in lockstep. The batch route already diverges slightly (adds `batchGraded: true` to aiMetadata). This is the kind of drift that introduces bugs over time.

## Suggested Fix

Extract two shared helpers in a file like `src/lib/grading-helpers.ts`:

1. `buildRubricInput(rubric, criteria, assignment)` -> returns `{ rubric: GradeSubmissionInput['rubric'], assignment: GradeSubmissionInput['assignment'] }`
2. `persistGradingResult(db, submissionId, teacherId, gradingResult, extraMeta?)` -> handles the feedbackDrafts insert, criterionScores insert, and submissions update

This collapses ~40 duplicated lines per file into single function calls.

data.title: Three route handlers have inline AI tool_use calls that bypass the AI service layer
data.description:
## Problem

The codebase has a well-structured AI service layer in `src/lib/ai/` with 13 modules that encapsulate all Claude API interactions. However, three route handlers bypass this layer and make direct `anthropic.messages.create()` calls with inline tool schemas:

1. **`src/app/api/early-warning/route.ts`** (lines 294-335) -- inline `student_interventions` tool for generating at-risk student recommendations
2. **`src/app/api/mastery/gaps/route.ts`** (lines 161-210) -- inline `suggest_reteach_activities` tool for reteaching suggestions
3. **`src/app/api/grading/differentiate/route.ts`** (lines 101-210) -- inline `differentiated_activities` tool for generating tiered follow-up activities

Each of these defines an inline tool schema, makes a direct API call, and extracts the tool_use block with the same boilerplate pattern. The existing `src/lib/ai/differentiate.ts` even exports `differentiateContent()` but is unused because the differentiate route handler reimplements the concept with a different (assessment-driven) approach.

## Why It Matters

- The AI service layer (`src/lib/ai/`) is the documented pattern for all Claude interactions. These three routes break that contract, making it harder for developers to find all AI call sites.
- The tool_use extraction boilerplate (find block, check type, cast input) is repeated 17 times across the codebase. Each inline call adds another copy.
- If the API configuration changes (model, max_tokens default, error handling), these three routes must be found and updated separately.

## Suggested Fix

Create three new AI service functions:
- `src/lib/ai/early-warning.ts` -> `generateStudentInterventions(flaggedStudents)`
- `src/lib/ai/mastery-gaps.ts` -> `generateReteachActivities(gapSummary)`
- Move the differentiate route's logic into the existing `src/lib/ai/differentiate.ts` as `generateDifferentiatedActivities(assignmentData, tiers)` alongside the existing `differentiateContent()`

Each route handler then becomes a thin orchestration layer: fetch data, call AI service, return response.

data.title: assignments/generate/route.ts creates its own Anthropic client and hardcodes model name
data.description:
## Problem

`src/app/api/assignments/generate/route.ts` is the only file in the codebase that creates its own Anthropic SDK instance:

```typescript
import Anthropic from '@anthropic-ai/sdk'
const anthropic = new Anthropic({ apiKey: process.env.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY })  // line 14
```

Every other file imports the singleton from `src/lib/ai.ts`:
```typescript
import { anthropic, AI_MODEL } from '@/lib/ai'
```

This route also hardcodes the model string `'claude-opus-4-6'` on line 76 instead of using the `AI_MODEL` constant.

Additionally, this route reimplements the Smart Assignment generation with an inline tool schema (~100 lines) despite `src/lib/ai/generate-assignment.ts` already exporting `generateSmartAssignment()` with a richer, more detailed version of the same tool schema.

## Why It Matters

- The global singleton in `src/lib/ai.ts` uses the `globalThis` pattern specifically to prevent multiple Anthropic client instances during Next.js hot-reload. This route bypasses that protection.
- If the model name changes, this route will be missed because it uses a literal string rather than the shared constant. Grep for `AI_MODEL` would not find it.
- The inline tool schema has less detailed property descriptions than the service version, which may produce lower-quality AI output.
- A previous code review identified this (TEAC-u9njg8) and it was closed as "won't fix." It remains the single largest pattern violation in the codebase.

## Suggested Fix

Replace the inline AI logic with a call to the existing service:

```typescript
import { generateSmartAssignment } from '@/lib/ai/generate-assignment'

const generated = await generateSmartAssignment({
  objective,
  subject,
  gradeLevel,
  type: type || 'essay',
  standards: standards ? [standards] : undefined,
})
```

Then use the returned structured data to persist to the database (the route's DB persistence logic is fine and should be kept).

data.title: Two message compose components with overlapping functionality
data.description:
## Problem

The codebase has two separate message compose components that both POST to `/api/messages` with the same payload shape:

1. **`src/components/messages/compose-message.tsx`** (ComposeMessage) -- Used on the messages list page (`src/app/dashboard/messages/page.tsx`). A Dialog-based component with contact loading, recipient selection, subject, and content fields.

2. **`src/components/messages/message-compose.tsx`** (MessageCompose) -- Used on the message detail page (`src/app/dashboard/messages/[messageId]/page.tsx`). A form component for replying to a specific recipient, with optional subject and content fields.

Both components:
- POST to `/api/messages` with `{ receiverId, subject, content, type: 'general' }`
- Have identical sending state management (setSending, try/catch, error handling)
- Use the same button styling (`bg-amber-600 hover:bg-amber-700 text-white`)
- Handle the same error patterns

The key difference is that ComposeMessage includes a contact picker (Select dropdown) while MessageCompose receives a fixed `receiverId` as a prop. MessageCompose also has an `isReply` mode for replies.

## Why It Matters

The message-sending logic (POST call, error handling, state management) is duplicated. If the messages API changes (e.g., new required field), both components must be updated. The naming is also confusing: `compose-message` vs `message-compose` requires reading the code to determine which is which.

## Suggested Fix

Extract the shared sending logic into a hook (`useMessageSend`) or consolidate into a single component with props to control whether a contact picker is shown. The ComposeMessage dialog could use MessageCompose internally as the form content, adding the dialog wrapper and contact picker on top.
